title: 108_s2245
content: The Act is titled the "Small Business Health Tax Credit Act" and introduces a small business tax credit for 50 percent of health premiums under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Small Business Health Tax Credit Act offers a tax credit for qualified small employers based on the percentage of employee health insurance expenses paid during the taxable year. The applicable percentage varies depending on the number of qualified employees, with limits on the amount of expenses per employee. The Small Business Health Tax Credit Act limits employee health insurance expenses for qualified small employers based on the maximum employer contribution for coverage determined under section 8906(a) of title 5, United States Code. Definitions and special rules apply, including eligibility requirements for small employers providing health insurance coverage to all qualified employees. The Small Business Health Tax Credit Act defines a small employer as having 2 to 50 qualified employees in the preceding calendar years, with special rules for new employers. The Small Business Health Tax Credit Act defines a small employer as having 2 to 50 qualified employees in the preceding calendar year, with special rules for new employers. The determination of qualified employee health insurance expenses is based on the average number of qualified employees that the employer will employ on business days in the current calendar year. Qualified employee health insurance expenses refer to amounts paid by an employer for health insurance coverage provided to qualified employees, excluding amounts paid under salary reduction arrangements. The term 'health insurance coverage' is defined as per section 9832(b), and a 'qualified employee' is an employee not provided health insurance coverage under specific plans or codes. The term 'employee' is defined as an individual expected to receive at least $5,000 in compensation from the employer in a calendar year, excluding certain types of employees. Compensation refers to specific amounts described in section 6051(a)(3), with rules similar to section 52 applying for clarification. The rules of section 52 apply to qualified employee health insurance expenses. No double benefit deduction or credit is allowed for these expenses. The employee health insurance expenses credit is part of the general business credit under section 38(b) of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit can be used against the minimum tax. The employee health insurance credit is subject to special rules. Section 39 and section 52 are applied separately to the credit. Amounts in subparagraphs (A) and (B) are treated as zero, and there are limitations under paragraph (1) for the credit. The employee health insurance credit is subject to special rules, with limitations under paragraph (1) for the credit. Conforming amendments are made to section 38(c)(2)(A)(ii) and section 38(c)(3)(A)(ii) of the Code. The employee health insurance credit is amended to prevent carrybacks of unused credits before the effective date. Clerical amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code. The IRS and Small Business Administration will develop an educational program to help businesses understand eligibility criteria, calculation methods, documentation requirements, and health plan purchasing alliances for the employee health insurance tax credit under section 45G of the Internal Revenue Code. Effective for taxable years after a specified date. The tax credit provisions apply to amounts paid or incurred in taxable years after the enactment of this Act.
